name: NPR
text:
Jagmeet Singh was expelled from Canada's parliament for the day after calling rival politician Alain Therrien "racist."

Therrien had opposed a motion to acknowledge systemic racism in the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
https://t.co/gwUsKGLWNW

name: NPR
text:
Leaders from Facebook, Twitter and Google told the House Intelligence Committee that their practices have prompted foreign influence-mongers to make some of their operations less clandestine and more overt.
https://t.co/ACq5aLELBb

name: NPR
text:
These students in Brooklyn see every day how climate change disproportionately affects their community. They made a podcast that asked: Why?

Their episode about environmental racism is one of this year's winners in the NPR Student Podcast Challenge.
https://t.co/9H0Y6vh8Jd

name: NPR
text:
What does anti-racist work look like for white people?

It’s sort of like working out, says Robin DiAngelo. It’s not going to happen overnight, and it’s going to take continual practice. You will never “arrive” — it's a journey. (@nprlifekit)
https://t.co/NVlpIzK2ws

name: NPR
text:
Opinion:

The acclaimed jazz trumpeter Terence Blanchard reflects on the song "What's Going On" by Marvin Gaye, arguing that it is time for well-meaning supporters to hear the words of Black protest — not just hum the melody.
https://t.co/uvFE34Lnfu

name: NPR
text:
In separate memos to staff, The New York Times and The Washington Post on Thursday evening announced new measures to address diversity and equity in their newsrooms and their coverage.
https://t.co/11NdxOMpDp

name: NPR
text:
"I feel like I have strong opinions weakly held," @phoebe_bridgers tells NPR. "Actually, it's stolen from a journalist buddy of mine, P.J. Vogt. He said that to me once and I was like 'Oh no! You see me!' It was horrible."
https://t.co/piJabLfSpO

name: NPR
text:
Questions about whether the political calendar in an election year holds sway over the search for a COVID-19 vaccine hung over Gen. Gustave Perna's confirmation hearing to lead that effort.
https://t.co/phYJc9uh7H

name: NPR
text:
Opposition to Israel’s annexing parts of the West Bank is mounting from what may seem like an unlikely group — Israeli settlers in the West Bank.
https://t.co/lUfIt3PqhT

name: NPR
text:
When Meg Remy started making music as U.S. Girls more than a decade ago, she played everything herself. 

Over time, that lineup has evolved: The latest album features up to 20 musicians recording in the studio at the same time.
https://t.co/Lg6p3LjLtx

name: NPR
text:
"What I really wanted to do was to write a song that felt like 'God Bless America,' " says Ketch Secor, the lead singer of Old Crow Medicine Show.

"These are troubling times and we need new songs about our country to inspire unity."
https://t.co/u9x47DIUoE

name: NPR
text:
The University of Georgia's marching band will no longer play a song from "Gone with the Wind" amid renewed criticism for the film's depiction of race.
https://t.co/UfvNoFigjY
